image.altText: A sign for the Launceston General Hospital and the Ashley Youth Detention Centre behind an obscured man.

items.synopsis: After 29 months, the Commission of Inquiry into the Tasmanian Government's Responses to Child Sexual Abuse in Institutional Settings has held its final hearing. Its president has called for change, saying more children will be abused without it.

title.children: Tasmanian child sex abuse inquiry refers more than 100 people to police and child protection

image.altText: An Indigenous flag held by a hand in a yellow, red and black parka

items.synopsis: Six years ago, while the sun crept up into the crevices of Uluru, history was being made by a few hundred First Nations people. Now, the rest of Australia can join in, writes Bridget Brennan.

title.children: This is a major moment in our history — and we may never get a re-run

image.altText: A middle-aged Aboriginal man raises his fist as two women standing beside him clap at a rally for the Yes campaign.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has announced a date for the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum. Look back on how it happened and the reaction in our blog.

title.children: The Voice referendum will happen on October 14, the PM has confirmed. How Australians reacted to the news

image.altText: The garden as it appeared in a 2020 listing

items.synopsis: Errol Stewart and his family company are facing charges over garden works at a heritage-listed Hobart property. Mr Stewart says the works were urgent, but the council says the works have damaged the heritage significance of the site.

title.children: 'It's my garden': Prominent developer defends changing heritage-listed garden without permit

image.altText: Dark storm clouds and lightning strikes in skies in south-east Queensland.

items.synopsis: A storm outbreak is set to hit broad parts of the east coast on Wednesday afternoon, with warnings of possible damaging winds and large hail for much of coastal New South Wales into south-east Queensland. Meanwhile, potentially record-breaking heat is building in the west.

title.children: Severe storms forecast for east coast as near-record-breaking heat builds in west

image.altText: PROXY: Qatar Qantas composite

items.synopsis: Two former heads of the national competition watchdog say the federal government's move to block Qatar Airways' request for extra flights to protect Qantas decreases competition and leaves travellers worse off.

title.children: 'I don't think anyone swallows that story': Flight Centre boss lashes federal government for putting Qantas before customers

image.altText: Katta O'Donnell wears a black turtleneck and long hair, standing in a forest in a portrait.

items.synopsis: The federal government has agreed to settle a world-first court case accusing it of misleading investors by failing to disclose the risk climate change poses to its bonds.

title.children: In 2020, a uni student launched a world-first case against the federal government. They’ve now reached an agreement

image.altText: Judge Salvatore Vasta

items.synopsis: An Australian man has been awarded more than $300,000, after his lawyer successfully argued he was wrongly jailed by a judge who behaved like a character from Alice In Wonderland.

title.children: Man awarded $300k after suing 'Queen of Hearts' judge for wrongful imprisonment

image.altText: Anthony Albanese standing in front of "VOTE YES" branding as he announces the date of the Voice to Parliament referendum

items.synopsis: Australians will cast their first referendum vote in more than two decades in October, deciding the fate of a constitutionally-enshrined Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice to Parliament.

title.children: October 14 set as Voice to Parliament referendum

image.altText: The Australian, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags are carried by fans on the Sydney Harbour Bridge.

items.synopsis: With the date set for a vote on the Voice to Parliament, take a refresher on what proponents and opponents of the referendum proposal are arguing.

title.children: What do Yes and No supporters argue about the Voice to Parliament?

image.altText: An older person's hand holds a slip of paper, dropping it into a box.

items.synopsis: When does voting open for the Voice to Parliament referendum? What is voting in a referendum like? When will we know the result? Get to grips with how the first referendum in two decades will work.

title.children: Everything you need to know about voting in the Voice referendum

image.altText: Ben Simmons sits and claps his hands

items.synopsis: Australia's first NBA All Star says he wants to join the Boomers as they try to defend or better their Olympic bronze medal from Tokyo, but he has made similar comments in the past.

title.children: 'My goal is to be on the Olympic team': Ben Simmons reveals Paris 2024 ambitions with Boomers

image.altText: A hand pointing a TV remote towards a TV, which displays the Netflix logo

items.synopsis: The streaming platform has always dominated the landscape, but for the first time since Netflix entered the Australian market — subscription numbers are down.

title.children: Is Netflix in its flop era? Subscribers are down for the first time since 2015

image.altText: Wooden marionette and shadows.

items.synopsis: In the beginning, he was charming, gentle and caring — but after she and her two children moved in with him, everything changed. Coercive control was at the centre of their relationship — with a court in Hobart hearing from three other victims of the same man.

title.children: 'You used and abused these women as you pleased': Hugs in court as man jailed over repeated abuse

image.altText: woman reads book on couch

items.synopsis: A doctor says better understanding of menopause will lead to better outcomes for women, particularly in the workplace.

title.children: Women fed up with suffering in silence say menopause is everyone's issue. Here's why

image.altText: A man looks on.

items.synopsis: When Luis Rubiales grabbed Jenni Hermoso's face and kissed her on the lips during post-match celebrations at Stadium Australia, Spaniards were forced to pick a side, and start a national conversation about chauvinism.

title.children: 'Something deeply rotten': Soccer, chauvinism and the national conversation Spain had to have

image.altText: A person shopping at Australian grocery store, with a basket full of sparkling water, fruits and vegetables.

items.synopsis: Inflation cooled more than forecast over the 12 months to July, with the ABS monthly index showing consumer prices easing to an annual pace of 4.9 per cent last month.

title.children: Inflation eases more than forecast in July but housing costs continue to rise

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: A rally on Wall Street has sent Australian stocks higher, while inflation fell to 4.9 per cent in the year to July. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX rises as inflation cools to 4.9pc

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Allan Fels and Rod Sims have both hit out at the federal government's decision to reject Qatar Airways' application for extra flights to protect Qantas, saying it disadvantages customers, is uncompetitive, and will keep airfares higher. It comes as a new report from the e61 Institute has raised concerns about the exercise of market power in Australia by dominant firms in concentrated markets. The report, The State of Competition in Australia, says the airline industry is one of the most concentrated in Australia, and suggests the power dynamics between airlines and their customers is "imbalanced". To read more on this story from myself and Gareth Hutchens, follow the link below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former ACCC bosses take aim at federal government over Qatar Airways decision

featuredLink.title: 'I don't think anyone swallows that story': Flight Centre boss lashes federal government for putting Qantas before customers

children.content: Allan Fels and Rod Sims have both hit out at the federal government's decision to reject Qatar Airways' application for extra flights to protect Qantas, saying it disadvantages customers, is uncompetitive, and will keep airfares higher.
It comes as
a new report from the e61 Institute has raised concerns about the exercise of market power in Australia by dominant firms in concentrated markets.
The report,
The State of Competition in Australia
, says the airline industry is one of the most concentrated in Australia, and suggests the power dynamics between airlines and their customers is "imbalanced".
To read more on this story from myself and Gareth Hutchens, follow the link below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has welcomed the pull back in inflation in July. “Business and consumers can feel a sense of relief, with inflation continuing to fall in July,” ACCI chief executive officer Andrew McKellar says. “The Reserve Bank’s interest rate rises have had a clear impact on economic activity and inflation." "Consumers have responded by cutting back spending on discretionary items such as holiday travel, furniture and household goods, and recreational activities." “The easing in prices of essential items such as fruit and vegetables will also alleviate some pressures on households.” And Mr McKellar has urged the RBA not to raise interest rates again. “While inflation is clearly on a downward trajectory, the Reserve Bank will be reluctant to take the pressure off the wound." "Businesses urge that the RBA stays its hand from any further interest rate hikes."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Relief for business as inflation falls

children.content: The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has welcomed the pull back in inflation in July.
“Business and consumers can feel a sense of relief, with inflation continuing to fall in July,”
ACCI chief executive officer
Andrew McKellar says.
“The Reserve Bank’s interest rate rises have had a clear impact on economic activity and inflation."
"Consumers have responded by cutting back spending on discretionary items such as holiday travel, furniture and household goods, and recreational activities."
“The easing in prices of essential items such as fruit and vegetables will also alleviate some pressures on households.”
And Mr McKellar has urged the RBA not to raise interest rates again.
“While inflation is clearly on a downward trajectory, the Reserve Bank will be reluctant to take the pressure off the wound."
"Businesses urge that the RBA stays its hand from any further interest rate hikes."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says today's inflation figure for July is an "encouraging result", and is now at the lowest level since February 2022 — months before the RBA started to lift interest rates. He said the data was "very welcome news because it shows we are making progress" at reducing inflation in the economy. "The ABS’s monthly CPI indicator rose 4.9% in the 12 months to July, the lowest outcome since February 2022 ," he said. "This is down from 5.4% in 12 months to June and much lower than the peak of 8.4% in the year to December 2022. "It's pleasing to see inflation is moderating but we know it will remain higher than we'd like for longer than we'd like." Mr Chalmers also said the federal government's energy bill relief package contributed to a smaller monthly rise in power prices. "In today's monthly CPI indicator, electricity prices increased 6% in the month of July," he said. "But without the Albanese government's energy bill relief that we're delivering in partnership with the states, the Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates electricity prices would have increased 19.2% over the same period."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Inflation figure 'shows we are making progress', Treasurer says

children.content: Treasurer Jim Chalmers
says today's inflation figure for July is an "encouraging result", and is now at the lowest level since February 2022 — months before the RBA started to lift interest rates.
He said the data was "very welcome news because it shows we are making progress" at reducing inflation in the economy.
"The ABS’s monthly CPI indicator rose 4.9% in the 12 months to July, the
lowest outcome since February 2022
," he said.
"This is down from 5.4% in 12 months to June and
much lower than the peak of 8.4%
in the year to December 2022.
"It's pleasing to see
inflation is moderating
but we know it will remain higher than we'd like for longer than we'd like."
Mr Chalmers also said the federal government's energy bill relief package contributed to a smaller monthly rise in power prices.
"In today's monthly CPI indicator, electricity prices increased 6% in the month of July," he said.
"But without the Albanese government's energy bill relief that we're delivering in partnership with the states,
the Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates electricity prices would have increased 19.2%
over the same period."

image.altText: Movie poster for the latest installment in the Hunger Games, 'Catching Fire'

items.synopsis: A report tabled in SA parliament finds that the state's Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions suffers from a "dysfunctional and broken" workplace culture where staff "don't feel safe, valued, heard or seen".

title.children: SA prosecutors' office likened to Hunger Games in damning review of workplace culture

image.altText: Black and white image of Troye Sivan. He is wearing a white tank top and sitting on a couch.

items.synopsis: Pop star Troye Sivan's latest album Something To Give Each Other will be released in October. But the first single has already become a dance-pop anthem. The singer chats about the success of Rush and how internet helped him share stories.

title.children: 'I am definitely a product of the internet': Troye Sivan gets candid about his music

image.altText: Darlington unit fire

items.synopsis: Police confirm that a body, believed to be a man aged in his 60s, has been located inside a Darlington unit following a fire on Wednesday morning.

title.children: Man's body found in burnt-out unit after blaze engulfed Sydney building

image.altText: A close-up of a woman with pink lipstick and blonde hair

items.synopsis: Annastacia Palaszczuk asks for privacy after being tracked down and photographed by the media during her two-week holiday in Italy.

title.children: 'Everyone is entitled to leave': Queensland premier requests privacy after being snapped on overseas holiday

image.altText: Man in suit stands in front of US flag

items.synopsis: In an operation dubbed "Duck Hunt", the FBI and partners seize control of malware network Qakbot, which has crippled millions of tech users for over 15 years.

title.children: 'Most devastating cybercriminal tools in history': Global investigation infiltrates malware network

image.altText: A composite image of five women, all smiling, with a soft green background.

items.synopsis: In any given year, at least 1 million Australian children and adults are living with an eating disorder. Five women have shared their experiences and hopes for a new road map on eating disorders.

title.children: 'Why don't I look like that'? Women share heartbreaking stories of life with an eating disorder

image.altText: A woman with short dark hair stares at her reflection in a mirror, without smiling.

items.synopsis: Australia now has a 10-year road map on eating disorders. Here’s a look at what it includes.

title.children: Australia's eating disorders strategy is a 'call to action'. But what happens next?

image.altText: Trees destroyed

items.synopsis: Trees covering the equivalent of 14 tennis courts of land have been cut and poisoned at Castle Cove, decimating important habitat for native animals.

title.children: 'Somebody could go to jail for it': $10k reward offered after 265 trees destroyed in Sydney waterfront reserve

image.altText: A composite image of blurred out cards and a man in a bright shirt

items.synopsis: The Anti-Defamation Commission has taken aim at the Australian-made game, which markets itself as being "ideal for the Aussie sense of humour".

title.children: Human rights group calls for 'immoral and obscene' game which mocks holocaust, rape and incest to be canned

image.altText: A woman with long dark hair and glasses stares out the window while grasping a cup of tea.

items.synopsis: Analysis of Federal Court data has found 10 per cent of all forced bankruptcies across Australia are from strata levy debts.

title.children: Nicki owns a flat, but has gone into debt due to strata fees

image.altText: A picture of a smiling man's face, attached to a wooden cross outside.

items.synopsis: At the Krasnopilske military cemetery in eastern Ukraine, one of the first things you hear is weeping — the women here all know each other, but they're bound together for devastating reasons.

title.children: Ukraine doesn't release its number of war casualties — at this cemetery, the real toll is on show

image.altText: Man casts vote in schoolroom

items.synopsis: Gunfire was heard in the capital of the Central African nation as senior military officials appeared on television, vowing to close borders and dissolve state institutions.

title.children: Military officials seize power in Gabon just hours after President Ali Bongo's re-election

image.altText: Tourists fish and drive at Lucky Bay

items.synopsis: Residents in the WA town of Esperance could be restricted from driving on its famous white beaches after an area of revegetation in a national park was damaged by four-wheel drivers.

title.children: Environmental 'vandalism at its worst' could lead to closure of one of world's best beaches for 4WDs

image.altText: Elaine Pandilovski smiles for a photo, dressed in a blue scarf and grey cardigan.

items.synopsis: The family of Elaine Pandilovski speak outside court as her estranged husband is sentenced for murdering the woman described as a "wonderful mother" in her Melbourne home in July, 2020.

title.children: 'Enough is enough': Family speaks out as man sentenced to 24 years' jail for murdering his wife

image.altText: A woman in a green blazer speaks at a press conference.

items.synopsis: Jackie Jarvis tells parliament of her abortion after being raped in the early 1990s and why she didn't report it, as politicians debate reforms to termination laws in parliament.

title.children: 'A clear decision': WA minister reveals she was victim of date rape, had abortion

image.altText: tall Gold Coast towers next to a beach

items.synopsis: Queensland is the top destination for those seeking a new adventure in their golden years, according to data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

title.children: Australians retiring later in life as thousands flock to Queensland, new data shows

image.altText: AI generated images of women from South Asia and East Asia

items.synopsis: AI-generated images of "beautiful" women from around the world have been going viral on TikTok. But some say they're based off stereotypes and can perpetuate colourist ideals.

title.children: Is there such thing as 'looking like' your ethnicity? These viral AI images think so
